paper_id: Flash Correct-and-Refresh: Retention-Aware Error Management for Increased Flash Memory Lifetime

triples.evidence: Detailed simulations of a solid-state drive (SSD) storage system driven by measured experimental data from error characterization on real flash memory chips show that our techniques provide 46x average lifetime improvement on a variety of workloads at no additional hardware cost.
With the continued scaling of NAND flash and multi-level cell technology, flash-based storage has gained widespread use in systems ranging from mobile platforms to enterprise servers.
Our evaluations show that hybrid and adaptive-rate FCR respectively provide 31x and 46x lifetime improvement at only 5.5% and 1.5% energy overhead.
Enterprise data storage systems typically require storage endurance capable of sustaining continuous 10 full disk writes per day for 3-5 years.
A 3x-nm (i.e., 30-39nm) generation MLC (2-bit per cell) NAND flash cell can be programmed only ~3k times.
Stronger error correcting codes (ECC) can be used to tolerate higher error rates, but these have diminishing returns with increasing P/E cycles.
The key idea is to periodically read, correct, and reprogram (in-place) or remap the stored data before it accumulates more retention errors than can be corrected by simple ECC.

axioms: uses rdfs:domain SSD; rdfs:range InternalFirmwareAndLogic/DataPath/Error Correction (ECC).
improves rdfs:domain InternalFirmwareAndLogic/DataPath/Error Correction (ECC); rdfs:range MetricsHealthAndState/Endurance.

mappings.notes: The paper discusses ECC as a method for error correction.

mappings.label: Retention Errors
mappings.notes: Retention errors are a type of error managed by ECC.
